questions.text: Dense irregular fascia is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

(Grays 41 ,page 39-40 ) probable Future question:

• Adult dermal collagen is mainly of types I and III, in proportions of 80–85% and 15–20% respectively.

• Type IV collagen is found in the basal lamina between epidermis and dermis, and around Schwann cells of peripheral nerves and endothelial cells of vessels.

Loose (areolar) connective tissue

• Submucosa in the digestive tract and other viscera lined by mucosae,
• subcutaneous tissue in regions devoid of fat (e.g. eyelids, penis, scrotum and labia),
• lamina propria of mucosal epithelia
• vascular endothelia,
• A variant of loose connective tissue occurs in the choroid and the sclera of the eye.

Dense irregular connective tissue

• Reticular layer of the dermis
• Superficial connective tissue sheaths of muscle and nerves
• Adventitia of large blood vessels
• Capsules of various glands and organs (e.g. testis, sclera of the eye, periostea and perichondria).

Regular connective tissues

• ligaments, tendons or Aponeurosis

questions.text: Physiologist conduct a study to identify the protein constituents present in normal pulmonary secretions. Bronchoalveolar lavage fluid obtained from a 34-years-old healthy volunteer is found to contain elastase. This enzyme is most likely derived from which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Alveolar macrophages

Elastase is a neutral protease contained in macrophage lysosomes and in the azurophilic (primary) granules of neutrophils. Normally, elastase release from alveolar macrophages and infiltrating neutrophils is balanced by the presence of serum and tissue protease inhibitors. Neutrophils elastase is inhibited by serum α1antitrypsin and macrophage elastase is inhibited by tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs). Neutrophil and macrophage elastases can also degrade each other’s (but not their own) inhibitors, augmenting their destructive capacity when both proteases are present. Excess protease activity is a major contributor to the development of both centriacinar and panacinar emphysema.

questions.text: Physicians involved in regenerative medicine research conduct a series of animal experiments to determine pulmonary tissue regeneration capacity. During one of the experiments, lung alveoli are exposed to NO2¬ and massive necrosis of the epithelial lining ensues. Histologic examination of the injured tissues a month later shows partial recovery of the alveolar epithelial lining. This regenerated tissue is most likely derived from which of the following cell types?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Type II pneumocytes

Explanation:

Ninety-five percent of the alveolar surface is covered by flat type I pneumocytes. The remaining 5% is covered by interspersed cuboidal type II pneumocytes that make up about 60% of the total number of alveolar cells. Type II pneumocytes are the source of pulmonary surfactant and have the ability to proliferate in response to injury. They also act as progenitor cells for type I pneumocytes, which cannot regenerate on their own.

questions.text: A 66-years-old man hospitalized 3 days ago for left lower lobe pneumonia is evaluated for persistent fever. Imaging studies reveal a loculated, left-sided pleural effusion. A tube is placed to drain the fluid via an incision at the 5th intercostal space in the midaxillary line. Which of the following muscles is most likely to be dissected during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Serratus anterior

This patient most likely has empyema requiring drainage with a chest tube. The technique involves placing the chest tube through the skin and subcutaneous fat into the 4th or 5th intercostal space in the anterior muscle, intercostal (external, internal, innermost) muscles, and parietal pleura to reach the pleural cavity.

The serratus anterior originates as multiple branches from the side of the chest along the 1st-8th ribs and inserts along the entire length of the medial scapular border. The muscle is divided into 3 parts (superior, intermediate, inferior) depending on the insertion site at the scapula. The inferior part of the muscle facilities arm elevation by pulling the lower end of the scapula forward (scapular rotation). All 3 muscle parts can help with respiration by lifting the ribs when the shoulder girdle is fixed.

questions.text: A 23-years-old man comes to the emergency department complaining that he has food stuck in his throat. His symptoms started 2 hours ago after eating fish at a local seafood restaurant. He has tried coughing and swallowing multiple times in an attempt to clear the food, but has so far been unsuccessful. The patient denies any difficulty with breathing. He does not appear to be in any distress on physical examination. Laryngoscopy reveals a fish bone lodged in the left piriform recess. During an attempt to retrieve the fish bone, a nerve is injured deep to the mucosa overlying the recess. Which of the following is most likely to be impaired in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Cough reflex

Explanation:
The piriform recesses are small cavities that lie on either side of the laryngeal orifice. They are bounded medially by the aryepiglottic folds and laterally by the thyroid cartilage and thyrohyoid membrane. During normal swallowing, food is diverted by the epiglottis laterally through the piriform recesses into the esophagus without endangering the airway.

A thin layer of mucosa overlying the piriform recess is all that protects the superficially coursing internal laryngeal nerve, a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve (CN X). Unlike the recurrent and external laryngeal nerves that carry motor fibers to the muscles involved in vocal cord function, the internal laryngeal nerve contains only sensory and autonomic fibers. It mediates the afferent limb of the cough reflex by carrying sensation from the mucosa superior to the vocal cords. Foreign bodies, such as chicken or fish bones, can become lodged in the piriform recess. The internal laryngeal nerve can be damaged by the sharpness of these objects or attempts to retrieve them.

questions.text: A 45-year-old Caucasian female presents to you with numbness of the right palm. After taking a detailed history and doing a physical examination, you suspect a median nerve lesion at the wrist. Before reaching the wrist, the median nerve courses between the:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Flexor digitorum superficial and flexor digitorum profundus muscles

The median nerve receives contributions from the C5 through T1 spinal nerves and emerges as a distinct structure from a combination of fibers from the lateral and medial cords of the brachial plexus. From this location, the median nerve courses with the brachial artery in the groove between the biceps brachii and the brachialis muscles. It gains access to the forearm in the medial aspect of the antecubital fossa and immediately courses between the humeral and ulnar heads of the pronator teres muscle. It then courses between the flexor digitorum superficialis and the flexor digitorum profundus muscles before entering the wrist and hand within the flexor retinaculum.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Supraspinatus

Exp:-

The rotator cuff is made up of the tendons of the following muscles: supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis (SITS).. The supraspinatus muscle is the main agonistic muscle responsible for the first 10 to 15 degrees of arm abduction. Of the rotator cuff structures, the tendon of the supraspinatus muscle is most commonly affected in rotator cuff syndrome. Due to its superior location, this tendon is vulnerable to chronic repeated trauma from impingement between the head of the humerus and the acromioclavicular joint. Motions that typically cause inflammation of this tendon are simultaneous abduction and flexion of the arm at the shoulder, but a traumatic fall laterally on an outstretched hand can also cause injury. Inflammation is followed by fibrosis, which worsens the problem by increasing friction between the head of the humerus and the acromion, as well as causing inflammation of the subacromial bursa.

The supraspinatus muscle assists in abduction of the arm and stabilization of the glenohumeral joint. The most commonly injured structure in rotator cuff syndrome is the tendon of the supraspinatus muscle. This tendon is vulnerable to injury due to impingement between the acromion and the head of the humerus.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man comes to the physician because of diplopia and a drooping right eyelid. His symptoms began 1 day ago and have since worsened. Physical examination shows a dilated right pupil that is nonreactive to both light and accommodation. There is vertical and horizontal diplopia. When the patient is asked to stare straight ahead, the right eye is directed interiorly and laterally with respect to his left eye. Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain shows an aneurysm involving the right posterior communicating artery. Which of the following muscles is most likely to remain functionally intact in this pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lateral rectus

Explanation:

This patient presents with a right third nerve (CN III) palsy secondary to a compressive aneurysm. Lesions involving CN III cause ptosis (drooping of the upper eyelid) and impair adduction, depression, and elevation of the eye. As a result, diagonal (eg, horizontal and vertical) diplopia is frequently present and the eye rests in a "down and out" position. Pupillary constriction and accommodation can also be affected as CN III carries parasympathetic fibers to the ciliary muscle and the iris sphincter.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old Caucasian female is brought to the emergency department with severe left-sided hip pain after falling in the bathroom. She is agitated and demands quick pain relief. A pelvic x-ray is shown below.

Which of the following arteries is most likely to be damaged in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Medial circumflex 

Expl. 

This patient's x-ray shows a nondisplaced left subcapital femoral neck fracture. Note below how the femoral neck is markedly shortened compared to the right side. 

Femoral neck fractures are common in elderly patients with osteoporosis who have sustained a fall. The femoral head and neck derive their blood supply from the superior and inferior gluteal arteries and the medial and lateral femoral circumflex arteries, vessels that together form the trochanteric anastomosis. The medial femoral circumflex artery makes the largest contribution to the blood supply of this region and is vulnerable to damage from femoral neck fractures due to its close association with the posterior aspect of the femoral neck. Injury or thrombosis of this vessel predisposes to avascular necrosis of the femoral head.

choices.text: The right main bronchus is longer than the left main bronchus
The right main bronchus is straighter than the left main bronchus
The right main bronchus is narrower than the left main bronchus
The right lower lobe receives a richer blood supply than the left lower lobe

questions.text: A 63-year-old male with a history of stroke and resultant severe oropharyngeal dysphagia develops a right lower lobe pneumonia after an episode of vomiting. This type of aspiration pneumonia commonly affects the right lower lung lobe because:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The right main bronchus is straighter than the left main bronchus 

Explanation:  

The right main bronchus is more prone to foreign body aspiration than the left main bronchus because the right main bronchus has a larger diameter, is shorter, and is oriented more vertically than the left main bronchus. This fact can be remembered using the mnemonic, "Swallow a bite, goes down the right."

Educational objective:
Aspirated or inhaled particles are most likely to become lodged in the right main bronchus or its branches because this bronchus is shorter wider and more vertically oriented than the left main bronchus.

questions.text: Pudendal nerve block abolishes pain from:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Inferior part of vagina

• Pudendal nerve supplies the structures in the perineum, including the opening of vagina.
Pelvic ciscera (including cervix and major portion of vagina) are supplied by the auronomic nervous system: Lumbar splanchnic nerves (sympathetic) and nervi erigentes (parasympathetic).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with abdominal tenderness and acute pain. On examination, her physician observes that an abdominal infection has spread retroperitoneally Which of the following structures is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Descending colon

Reference – Read the text below

Sol:   

• The descending colon is a retroperitoneal organ. The rest of the organs are surrounded by peritoneum.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes in with a stab wound, cannot raise his arm above horizontal, and exhibits a condition known as winged scapula. Which of the following structures of the brachial plexus would most likely be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Roots

Reference – Read the text below

Sol:   

• Winged scapula is caused by paralysis of the serratus anterior muscle that results from damage to the long thoracic nerve, which arises from the roots of the brachial plexus (C5-C7).

choices.text: It is separated from adjacent segments by connective tissue septa.
It is the largest subdivision of a lobe.
It is named according to the segmental bronchus supplying it.

questions.text: All of the following statements correctly apply to a bronchopulmonary segment except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It is not resectable.

Reference – Read the text below

Sol:   

• A bronchopulmonary segment is a pyramidshaped segment of the lung with its apex facing the lung root and its base at the pleural surface.

• It is the largest subdivision of a lobe and is sepa-rated from adjacent segments by connective tissue.

• It is surgically resectable

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman complains of headache and dizziness after hitting a kitchen cabinet door with her head. Her magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan and venogram show a large blood clot in the great cerebral vein of Galen. The obstructed vein of the brain is a direct tributary of which of the following venous structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dural venous sinuses

 Ref– Read the text below 

Sol:  

• The veins of the brain are direct tributaries of the dural venous sinuses.

• The emissary veins connect the dural venous sinuses with the veins of the scalp; the pterygoid venous plexus communicates with the cavernous sinus through an emissary vein; the diploic veins lie in channels in the diploc of the skull and communicate with the dural sinuses, the veins of the scalp, and the meningeal veins.

choices.text: It is first bone to start ossifying
It acts like a strut to keep upper limb away from the trunk
It commonly fractures at the junction of its lateral two-third and medial one-third
It can be palpated throughout its extent

questions.text: All the statements about clavicle are correct except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It commonly fractures at the junction of its lateral two-third and medial one-third.

questions.text: TRUE about spermatid:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Derived from secondary spermatocyte

• Spermatid is the haploid male gamete that results from division of secondary spermatocytes.

• As a result of meiosis, each spermatid contains only half of the genetic material present in the original primary spermatocyte.

• Spermatids undergo spermiogenesis (and not any division) to form the spermatozoa.

questions.text: True about primitive streak are all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Appear at cranial end

• Primitive streak appears at the caudal end of the embryo.

questions.text: Sympathetic ganglion develops from:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Neural crest

• Most of the ganglia are derived from neural crest cells, including sympathetic ganglia.

questions.text: Spleen develops from:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dorsal mesogastrium

• Spleen develops in cephalic part of dorsal mesogastrium from its left layer.

questions.text: Ventral pancreatic duct give rise to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Uncinate process

• Pancreas develops from the two pancreatic buds:

• The larger one is dorsal pancreatic bud and forms the major portion of pancreas.

• The smaller one is ventral pancreatic bud, which forms the lower part of the head and uncinate process of pancreas.

questions.text: Mesonephric derivatives are all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Glomerulus.

• Glomerulus (excretory system) is derived from ‘metanephric’ blastema (and not mesonephros).

• Mesonephric duct gives ureteric bud to form the collecting system of kidney (and not excretory system).

• Wolffian system (developing from Mesonephric duct) gives male reproductive tubes (and becomes vestigial in females).

• Woffian system in males forms: Epididymis, Vas deferens, Seminal vesicle, Common ejacularoty ducts, etc.

• Vestigial remnanat of Wolffian (mesonephric) system in females are: Epi-oophoron, Para-oophoron, Gartener’s duct.

questions.text: Clavipectoral fascia is pierced by all of the following structures except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Medial pectoral nerve

questions.text: Merkel cells are derivatives of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Surface ectoderm > b. Neural crest cell origin

• Earlier merkel cells were considered to be derived from neural crest cells (gray’s Anatomy – 40th Edition), but more recent studies have indicated that they are in fact epithelial (Gray’s Anatomy – 41st Edition) in origin.

• Since skin epithelium is derived from surface ectoderm, the merkel cells are derivative of surface ectoderm.

questions.text: All of the following structures form the boundary of triangle of auscultation except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rhomboideus major

choices.text: It is the point on the upper trunk of brachial plexus where six nerves meet
Traction injury of Erb’s point involves C5 and C6 fibres
Suprascapular and nerve to subclavius arise at this point
Dorsal scapular and long thoracic nerves arise at this point

questions.text: Select the incorrect statement about the Erb’s point:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dorsal scapular and long thoracic nerves arise at this point

choices.text: It is a saddle type of synovial joint
Its articular surfaces are covered with fibrocartilage
It is frequently involved in dislocation
Its joint cavity is divided into two parts by an articular disc

questions.text: All of the following statements about sternoclavicular joint are true except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It is frequently involved in dislocation

questions.text: All of the following structures are present in the deltopectoral groove except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Basilic vein

choices.text: Its long head arises from infraglenoid tubercle of scapula
It is capable of affecting movements at glenohumeral, elbow and superior radio-ulnar joints
It is supplied by musculocutaneous nerve

questions.text: Select the incorrect statement about the biceps brachii muscle:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Its long head arises from infraglenoid tubercle of scapula

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician complaining of easy fatigability. She lives alone and works as an accountant. Her menstrual cycles are regular and her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. Her blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg and pulse is 82/min. During her physical examination, she sits up from the supine position without using her hands. Which of the following muscles contributes most to the described movement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Psoas major

Major muscles used when sitting up from the supine position include the external abdominal obliques, the rectus abdominis, and the hip flexors. The psoas major and iliacus contribute most significantly to the hip flexion;

choices.text: Spiral fracture of the humeral midshaft

questions.text: A 33-year-old male slips while working in his yard and falls on outstretched hands. He later presents to the emergency room complaining of right shoulder pain. On physical examination, there is flattening of the right deltoid muscle and insensitivity of the overlying skin to pinprick. Which of the following injuries is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Anterior dislocation of the humerus

Exp:- The glenohumeral joint is the most commonly dislocated joint in the body owing to the shallow articulation between the humeral head and the glenoid fossa of the scapula. The shoulder may dislocate anteriorly, interiorly or posteriorly, but anterior dislocations are by far the most common. Flattening of the deltoid muscle after a shoulder injury suggests anterior shoulder dislocation. This injury most commonly results from forceful external rotation and abduction at the shoulder joint. Axillary nerve injury, resulting in deltoid paralysis and loss of sensation over the lateral arm, is often associated

questions.text: A 52-year-old golfer presents to you with right shoulder pain that has started to interfere with his daily activities, such as getting dressed. Imaging studies suggest calcification of the supraspinatus tendon. Which of the following is most likely to provoke pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Abduction of the humerus  

The most commonly injured structure in rotator cuff syndrome is the tendon of the supraspinatus muscle. Because the supraspinatus is an abductor of the humerus, injury to its tendon causes pain on abduction of the arm.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman with metastatic lung cancer complains of recent hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. On examination, there is loss of the gag reflex on the left side and uvula deviation to the right when the patient is prompted to say “ah.” There is also weakness of her left sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. A lesion involving which of the following anatomical structures is most likely responsible for the patient's symptoms'?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Jugular foramen

This patient's symptoms are consistent with a lesion involving the jugular foramen, a large aperture located in the base of the skull behind the carotid canal It is formed by the petrous portion of the temporal bone and the occipital bone. Passing though the jugular foramen are CN IX, X, and XI. Lesions of the jugular foramen (from tumors, trauma, or infection) can result in jugular foramen (Vernet) syndrome, which is characterized by CN IX, X, and XI dysfunction Symptoms are related to the nerve affected

• Loss of taste from the posterior 1/3 of the tongue (CN IX)

• Reduced parotid gland secretion (CN IX) m Loss of gag reflex (CN IX, X)

• Dysphagia (CN IX, X)

• Dysphonia/hoarseness (CN X)

• Soft palate drop with deviation of the uvula toward the normal side (CN X)

• Sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscle paresis (CN XI)

questions.text: A 7-year-old male has a right leg cast after a bicycle accident. After wearing the cast for some time, he complains of pain and numbness of the dorsum of his right foot and cannot dorsiflex his right ankle. Which of the following is the most likely site of nerve compression in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fibular neck

Trauma or sustained pressure to the neck of the fibula can cause injury to the common peroneal nerve as it courses superficially and laterally to this structure

questions.text: A 34-year-old male has difficulty walking after sustaining a traumatic injury to his right leg. Physical examination reveals a right foot that is dorsiflexed and everted. The patient is unable to stand on his tiptoes. What is the most likely area of sensory loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Plantar foot

The tibial nerve innervates the flexors of the lower leg, the extrinsic digital flexors of the toes, and the skin of the sole of the foot.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male presents to you with difficulty walking. On gait examination, you note that he leans to the right side while walking. When he is asked to stand on his left foot, his right hip tilts significantly downward. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Superior gluteal 

1. Injury to the superior gluteal nerve causes weakness of the gluteus medius and producing a positive Trendelenburg test.

2. The inferior gluteal nerve innervates the gluteus maximus muscle. Injury of the inferior gluteal nerve causes difficulty rising from the seated position and climbing stairs.

questions.text: A 24-year-old mountain climber presents to the emergency room with right shoulder pain following a fall. He was climbing a cliff ,he lost his grip and fell approximately 5 meters onto the boulders below. He says that he "landed on his right arm and heard the bone snap". Physical examination reveals total inability to extend the right wrist. X-ray reveals a fracture of the right humeral shaft. Which of the following arteries is most likely to be injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Deep brachial artery

The deep brachial artery and radial nerve course along the posterior aspect of the humerusr Midshaftfractures of the humerus risk injury to these structures. Supracondylar fractures are associated with injury to the brachial artery.

questions.text: A 12-year-old soccer player presents to the emergency room with acute right knee pain after sustaining a kick injury to an extended leg. The trauma caused anterior displacement of her tibia with respect to her femur. Which of the following ligaments was most likely injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Anterior cruciate 

The anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) can be damaged by forceful anterior motion of the tibia with respect to the femur.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female presents to you complaining of "right hand clumsiness." Physical examination reveals decreased sensation over the fifth finger and a flattened hypothenar eminence. The affected nerve is commonly injured at which of the following locations'?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hook of the hamate 

Ulnar nerve injury classically causes a "claw hand" deformity. The ulnar nerve can be injured either near the medial epicondyle of the humerus or in Guyon's canal near the hook of the hamate and pisiform bone in the wrist.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of right-sided testicular swelling He first noticed the swelling 1 week ago while getting ready for work. He denies any testicular pain or history of trauma However, he has noticed a heavy, pressing sensation involving his scrotum and lower abdomen Physical examination reveals asymmetric swelling of the right testis, and subsequent ultrasonography shows a solid testicular mass. If malignant, this patient's tumor is most likely to spread to which of the following lymph node groups?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Para-aortic

Lymph from the testes drains through lymph channels directly back to the para-aortic lymph nodes. In contrast, lymph from the scrotum drains to the superficial inguinal lymph nodes

questions.text: A 34-year-old male presents to the emergency room complaining of severe right shoulder pain after falling from a tree. X-ray reveals a fracture in the middle third of the right clavicle. The medial end of the fractured clavicle is displaced upward due to traction by the:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Sternocleidomastoid muscle

The sternocleidomastoid muscle originates on the medial clavicle and manubrium and inserts on the mastoid process of the skull. It is innervated by CN XI and functions to turn the head in the opposite direction

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with advanced bladder carcinoma suffers from compression of a nerve that passes through the obturator foramen. Which of the following functions would be most affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Adduction of the thigh 

The obturator nerve is the only major nerve that exits the pelvis through the obturator foramen. This nerve supplies the muscles of the medial (adductor) compartment of the thigh and can be damaged during pelvic surgery, especially in procedures such as lymph node dissection

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of persistent left wrist pain. While walking his dog 5 hours ago, he fell forward to the ground and landed on his outstretched left hand. Examination shows mild swelling over the dorsum of the left hand with preserved range of motion. There is point tenderness present over the anatomic snuffbox. An x-ray of his left wrist is shown below.

This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Avascular necrosis

Fall on an outstretched hand may cause fracture of the scaphoid bone. Examination shoy^ tenderness in anatomical snuff box. The scaphoid bone is vulnerable to avascular necrosis and nonunion due to its tenuous blood supply.

questions.text: A 46-year-old gardener presents to you with knee pain. He reports that he spends hours on his knees several times per week while gardening. Which of the following bursae do you most expect to be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Prepatellar bursa

Repeated and prolonged kneeling can cause prepatellar bursitis. Dubbed "housemaid's knee," today it is most commonly seen in roofers, carpenters and plumbers. Signs and symptoms of prepatellar bursitis include knee pain, erythema, swellina and inability to kneel on the affected side.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male fractures his right tibia in a motor vehicle accident. His right leg is fixed in a cast, and he requires crutches to ambulate. Two weeks later, he presents with difficulty extending his wrist. Injury to which of the following nerves is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Radial nerve

Improperly fitted crutches can cause radial nerve injury, resulting in weakness of all forearm, wrist and finger extensors ("wristdrop").

questions.text: A 64-year-old Caucasian male loses consciousness near the entrance to an emergency room A physician rushes to the patient and palpates a strong pulse along the inner side of the sternocleidomastoid muscle The vessel palpated by the doctor is a derivative of which of the following aortic arches?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The first aortic arch gives rise to a portion of the maxillary artery, and the secondaortic arch gives rise to the stapedial artery, which typically regresses in humans.The fifth aortic arch completely regresses, leaving no structures or vestiges in the adult. The third aortic arch forms the common and proximal internal carotid arteries.The fourth aortic arch gives rise to part of the true aortic arch and a portion of thesubclavian arteries. The sixth aortic arch gives rise to the pulmonary arteries and the ductusarteriosus.

choices.text: External carotid artery, facial artery, ophthalmic artery, retinal artery
Internal carotid artery, ophthalmic artery, retinal artery
External carotid artery, temporal artery, retinal artery
Internal carotid artery, anterior cerebral artery, retinal artery

questions.text: A 71-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to sudden-onset vision loss in his left eye for one hour. He has a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Blood pressure is 145/80 mm Hg and pulse is 72/min. On examination, the patient can see only hand motions through the left eye. Funduscopic evaluation of the eye shows a cherry-red spot in the macula with surrounding retinal whitening. Cranial nerve examination is otherwise unremarkable. There is a left-side neck bruit on cardiovascular examination. Which of the following is the most likely path of the embolus causing the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Internal carotid artery, ophthalmic artery, retinal artery

Retinal artery occlusion is a cause of acute, painless, monocular vision loss. It is usually caused by thromboembolic complications of atherosclerosis travelling from the internal carotid artery and through the ophthalmic artery.

choices.text: Immediately lateral to the femoral artery
Immediately medial to the femoral artery
Midway between the iliac crest and the femoral artery
Superior and medial to the pubic tubercle

questions.text: An 82-year-old woman is sent to the hospital from a nursing home after 2 days of fever, confusion, and lethargy The patient has a history of mild dementia, hypertension, and osteoarthritis. A femoral venous access is planned for administration of intravenous fluids and antibiotics The femoral artery pulsation is palpable immediately below the inguinal ligament. Which of the following describes the optimal cannulation site for the femoral vein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Immediately medial to the femoral artery

The femoral triangle (lateral to medial) consists of the femoral nerve, femoral artery,femoral vein, and deep inguinal nodes/lymphatic vessels Cannulation of the femoralvein should occur approximately 1 cm below the inguinal ligament and just medial tothe femoral artery pulsation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for repeated vomiting that began 2 hours ago. The patient has a history of dyspepsia after meals, for which he takes over-the-counter antacids. Physical examination reveals mild epigastric tenderness. Endoscopy shows a deep, bleeding ulcer on the posterior wall of the duodenal bulb This ulcer has most likely penetrated which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Gastroduodenal

The gastroduodenal artery lies along the posterior wall of the duodenal bulb and is likely to be eroded by posterior duodenal ulcers. Ulceration into the gastroduodenal artery can be a source of life-threatening hemorrhage.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of swelling in his groin that he first noticed 2 weeks ago Physical examination shows a bulge above the inguinal ligament that increases in size when the patient is asked to cough. He is referred to a surgeon and scheduled to undergo elective laparoscopic hernia repair. Which of the following landmarks will best aid the surgeon in distinguishing an indirect from a direct inguinal hernia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Inferior epigastric vessels 

Indirect inguinal hernias are located lateral to the inferior epigastric vessels They can continue into the scrotum and are felt by deep palpation of the external inguinal ring with the tip of the finger. In contrast, direct inguinal hernias are located medially to the inferior epigastric vessels. They do not protrude into the scrotum and are best felt with the pulp of the finger

questions.text:
A patient is being evaluated for recurrent urinary tract infections. Her abdominal CT scan is shown below.

Which of the following most likely prevented the proper ascent of the anomalous organ seen on the CT scan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Inferior mesenteric artery 

In horseshoe kidney, both kidneys are fused together at the poles in early embryonic life. The isthmus of horseshoe kidney usually lies anterior to the aorta and inferior vena cava and posterior to the inferior mesenteric artery. This centrally located isthmus becomes trapped behind the inferior mesenteric artery during the relative ascent of the kidney

questions.text: A 37 year old previously healthy man comes for evaluation of enlarged lymph nodes. He has an 8 week history of progressively enlarging cervical lymph nodes associated with subjective fever, fatigue & drenching night sweat. After initial assessment the patient undergoes excisional biopsy of enlarged lymph nodes in the posterior triangle of neck. Two weeks later during a follow up visit, he describe difficulty in overhead activities such as combing his hair or placing dishes in the overhead shelves. Examination shows a left shoulder droop with weakness of left arm abduction above the horizontal position. Other shoulder movements are normal & there is no sensory loss. Which of the following muscle is most likely paralyzed in this patient –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Trapezius  

Spinal accessory nerve is injured in the posterior triangle and will lead to paralysis of Trapezius.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male presents to your office complaining of periodic, tight, burning substernal chest pain A thallium stress test shows hypoperfusion of the cardiac muscle forming the diaphragmatic surface of the heart Which of the following coronary arteries is most likely occluded in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Right coronary artery 

The inferior wall of the left ventricle forms most of the diaphragmatic surface of the heart. The posterior descending artery supplies this area. In 85-90% of individuals, the posterior descending artery derives from the right coronary artery.

questions.text: Smallest muscle in the body is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Stapedius

Ref: Read the text below

Sol : 

• The smallest skeletal muscle in the body is stapedius.

• The smallest muscle in the body is arrector pilorum, a smooth muscle in the skin for erection of hair.

questions.text: Floor of 4th ventricle has:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vagal triangle

Ref: Read the text below

Sol : 

• Floor of 4th ventricle has areas related to Abducent (6), vestiblar (8), vagus (10), hypoglossal (12) nuclei.

questions.text: Length of prostatic urethra is -
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

4 cm                     

Ref: Read the text below

Sol : 

• The length of prostatic urethra is 4 cm.  

• Membranous urethra lies in the deep perinial pouch  ( 1.5 – 2 cm ) & the penile urethra is 15 – 20 cm. 

• Length of female urethra is 4 cm.

questions.text: The third week of development is characterized by the appearance of the Pharyngeal apparatus, the embryonic primordium from which head and neck structures will be derived.Which of the following structures develop from the second Pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Posterior digastric muscle

Reference – Read the text below

Sol:   

• The posterior digastric muscle is derived from the second branchial arch and thus is innervated by its nerve, the facial (Seventh cranial) nerve.

• The anterior digastric muscle is derived from the first branchial arch and is innervated by its nerve, the mandibular division of the trigeminal (fifth cranial) nerve.

• The posterior cricoarytenoideus muscle and the superior constrictor muscle,derived from a combination of the fourth and sixth branchial arches, are innervated by the vagus (tenth cranial) nerve.

• The stylopharyngeus is derived from the third branchial arch and is the only voluntary muscle innervated by the glossopharyngeal (ninth cranial) nerve.

questions.text: Special feature of a thoracic vertebra is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Costal facets on bodies

questions.text: A 43-year-old man has new onset of difficulty with speaking. Examination reveals problems in elevating the hyoid bone and floor of the mouth, secondary to paralysis of the posterior belly of the digastric muscle. Which of the following nerves is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Facial nerve

Ref– Read the text below 

Sol:  

• The digastric posterior belly is innervated by the facial nerve, whereas the digastric anterior belly is innervated by the trigeminal nerve.

• The accessory nerve supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. The ansa cervicalis innervates the infrahyoid (or strap) muscles.

The glossopharyngeal nerve supplies the stylopharyngeus muscle

questions.text: Pubic symphysis is which type of joint?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cartilaginous

• Pubic symphysis is a secondary cartilaginous joint, which is slightly mobile.

questions.text: Muscle having double nerve supply:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Adductor magnus

Adductor magnus ischial part is supplied by tibial part of sciatic nerve and adductor part by obturator nerve.

questions.text: Which among the following is an intra-articular tendon is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Popliteus

• Popliteus has intracapsular origin from the lateral femoral epicondyle. It inserts on the posterior surface of the tibia, just proximal to the soleal line.

questions.text: Thoracic duct opens into:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Left brachiocephalic vein

• Thoracic  duct opens into the left venous (jugulo-subclavian) angle, at the beginning of left brachio-cephalic vein.

questions.text: Fertilization is complete when:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

2nd polar body is formed

• At fertilization, the secondary oocyte completes meiosis II to form a mature oocyte (23, 1N) and a second polar body.

questions.text: Regarding Meckel’s diverticulum all are true EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

3” long

• Meckel’s diverticulum is an outpouching(fingerlike pouch) of the ileum, derived from an unobliterated vitelline duct and located 2 feet proximal to the ileocecal junction on the antimesenteric side.

• It is a true diverticulum having all the layers of gut tube.

• It is approximately 2 inches long, occurs in approximately 2% of the population.

questions.text: Which of the following is a derivative of paramesonephric duct in males:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Prostatic utricle

• Prostatic utricle is a vestigial remnant of mullerian (paramesonephric) duct.

• Trigone of bladder develop from the mesonephric duct .

• Para-oophoron, and gartener’s duct are vestigial remnants of Wolffian (mesonephric) duct.

questions.text: Preaxial border of limb is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Radial border of forearm

• Pre-axial border of upper limb is the radial border and for lower limb it is the tibial border.

questions.text: Mammary gland is a type of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Modified sweat gland

• Mammary gland is a modified sweat gland of apocrine variety.

questions.text: Middle piece of sperm contains:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mitochondria

• Midpiece has a central filamentous core with numerous mitochondria spiraled around it, used for ATP production for the journey through the female genital tract.

• Most of the energy for sperm motility is derived from the metabolism of fructose carried in the seminal fluid.

questions.text: Ventricles of brain are lined by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Ependymocytes

• Ependymocytes are cuboidal or columnar in shape with tuft of cilia on their luminal surfaces and constitute the majority of the ependymal cells that line the ventricles of the brain and central canal of the spinal cord.

questions.text: Temporal lobe contains:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Primary auditory area

• Primary auditory area (41, 42) is present in the superior temporal gyrus (Heschl’s gyrus).

questions.text: All of the following nerves have general visceral fibers EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Olfactory

• Olfactory nerve belongs to SSA (Special Somatic Afferent) neural column.

• Cranial nerve 1,2, and 8 are under SSA. These nerve brings special sensations (Smell, vision, hearing and balance) from the periphery.

• GVE (General Visceral Efferent) neural column belongs to autonomic nervous system and supplies the three effectors: Cardiac muscles, smooth muscles and glands. It includes Oculomotor nerve , Facial nerve, glossopharyngeal nerve and Vagus nerve.

questions.text: Tract present in middle cerebellar peduncle is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pontocerebellar

• Middle cerebellar peduncle has incoming (afferent) fibers from the contralateral pons (ponto-cerebellar) fibers.

• Dentato-thalamic fibers pass through superior cerebellar peduncle from the dentate nucleus to synapse in thalamus.

• Posterior spin-cerebellar and the olivo cerebellar fibers pass through the inferior cerebellar peduncle.

questions.text: Ligamentum denticulatum has how many pair of teeth like projections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The pia mater of the spinal cord has a pair of denticulate ligaments (one on each side of the spinal cord) with 21 attachments which attach it to the arachnoid and dura mater.

questions.text: Parasympathetic fibres to eye come via:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Ciliary ganglion

• Parasympathetic supply to eye is controls the smooth muscles – sphincter papillae and ciliaris.

• Edinger-Westphal nucleus sends pre-ganglionic fibres through oculomotor nerve to reach ciliary ganglion.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic male presents with fever, headache and right eyelid pain. Examination reveals vesicles in upper eye lid, forehead and nose on the right side of face consistent with herpes zoster. Which of the following nerves is likely involved:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ophthalmic nerve

• Ophthalmic nerve (trigeminal nerve) aupplies the forehead region, upper eyelid and nose and the presentation is consistent with the herpes spread along the course of the nerve.

questions.text: Write the main action of marked muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

marked muscle – Temporalis . it does Retraction and Elevation both but its posterior fibres are only source of Mandibular retrusion.

So, Its  the main action is Retraction (Retrusion) > Elevation

choices.text: Inserts in inner part of 1st rib

questions.text: FALSE about scalenus anterior muscle:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Forms floor of posterior triangle

• Phrenic nerve runs on the anterior surface of scalenus anterior muscle, covered by prevertebral fascia.

• Scalenus anterior inserts on the first rib, but is not at the floor of posterior triangle of neck.

• Muscles at the floor are: Scalenus medius, levator scapulae, splenius capitis, semispinalis capitis.

questions.text: First branch of external carotid artery:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ascending Pharyngeal artery > a. Superior thyroid artery

questions.text: All of the following are branches of the external carotid artery EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Transverse cervical artery

• Transverse cervical artery is a branch of thyrocervical trunk, which itself is a branch of subclavian artery.

• Superior thyroid artery and lingual arteries are anterior branches of external carotid artery.

The only medial branch of external carotid artery is named as the ascending pharyngeal artery

choices.text: Serratus anterior and trapezius involved in abduction
Produced by multipennate fibres of deltoid
Axillary nerve injury has no effect on abduction
Rotator cuff stabilizes shoulder during abduction

questions.text: All of the following are True regarding abduction at the shoulder joint Except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Axillary nerve injury has no effect on abduction .

choices.text: Stenson’s duct opens behind upper 3rd molar
Divided by branches of facial nerve into superficial and deep lobes
Only benign tumours arise from parotid gland

questions.text: True statement(s) about parotid gland is/are?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Divided by branches of facial nerve into superficial and deep lobes

Parotid gland

• Largest salivary gland

• Purely serous gland

• The facial nerve forms the parotid plexus within the gland and separates the glandular tissue partially into superficial and deep layers ("lobes").

• Duct opens opposite upper 2nd molar

• Lymph nodes occur in the skin overlying the parotid gland (preauricular nodes) and in the substance of the gland

• Benign as well as malignant tumours may arise

questions.text: Meckel’s cave is related to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Trigeminal ganglion

• Meckel’s cave is a recess of the dura mater present in relation to the attached outer margin of the tentorium cerebelli near the apex of petrous temporal bone.

questions.text: True about Falx cerebri:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Contains straight sinus

• Falx cerebri is a sickle shaped dural fold which separates right and left cerebral hemishphere and contains superior sagittal, inferior sagittal and straight sinuses in it.

• Tentorium cerebelli separates cerebellum from occipital lobes of cerebrum.

• Falx cerebelli is a sickle shaped dural fold that extends between and separate two cerebellar hemispheres and contains occipital sinus in its posterior attached part.

questions.text: Tributaries of cavernous sinus are all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Superior cerebral vein

• Superior cerebral veins (eight to twelve) drain the superior, lateral, and medial surfaces of the hemispheres  into the superior sagittal sinus.

questions.text: Protrusion of tongue NOT possible in damage of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Genioglossus

• Posterior part of genioglossus pulls tongue anteriorly for protrusion.

• It is also called safety muscle of tongue as it prevents backward fall of tongue into the oral cavity, especially if the patient is unconscious.

questions.text: Lobes of submandibular gland are divided by which muscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Mylohyoid

• Submandibular gland wraps around the posterior border of mylohyoid.

• Thus, the gland has a large part superficial to the muscle and a small part which lies deep to the muscle.

questions.text: Nerve which loops around submandibular duct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lingual nerve

• Submandibular duct runs medial to and then superior to the lingual nerve (lingual nerve loop under submandibular duct).

questions.text: Lower border of pharynx is the level of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

C6

• Pharynx, the upper portion of gut tube, is funnel-shaped fibromuscular tube that extends from the base of the skull to the inferior border of the cricoids cartilage at the level of C6 vertebra.

• It continues inferiorly as the esophagus.

choices.text: Where it crosses left main brouchus

questions.text: Second constriction in esophagus is seen at the following site:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Crossing of aorta

• Second constriction of esophagus lies at the level of crossing of arch of aorta (23 cm from upper incisors).

questions.text: Nerve supply of larynx above level of vocal cord:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Superior laryngeal

• Laryngeal mucosa up to the level of the vocal folds is innervated by the internal laryngeal nerve (branch of superior laryngeal nerve).

• Recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies it below the vocal cords

questions.text: Lobule of ear supplied is by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Greater auricular nerve

• Greater auricular nerve supplies the lobule of ear on medial (cranial) as well as lateral (outer) surface.

questions.text: One of the following opens in the middle meatus of the nose:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Maxillary air sinus

• Maxillary sinus opens in the hiatus semilunaris of middle meatus near the roof of the sinus.

• Nasolacrimal duct opens into the anterior part of inferior meatus closed by a mucosal flap called Hasner’s valve.

• Eustachian tube opens into the lateral wall of nasopharynx, about 1.25 cm behind the posterior end of inferior nasal concha.

• Sphenoid air sinus opens into spheno-ethmoidal recess of nasal cavity.

questions.text: Lamina papyracea separates nose from:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Orbit

• Lamina papyracea is a smooth, oblong bone plate which forms the lateral surface of the labyrinth of the ethmoid bone.

• The plate covers in the middle and posterior ethmoidal cells and forms a large part of the medial wall of the orbit.

• It is paper-thin and fractures easily.

choices.text: Junction of lacrimal sac and canaliculus

questions.text: Valve of Rosenmuller is located at:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Junction of lacrimal sac and canaliculus

• Valve of Rosenmuller is a fold of mucous membrane at the junction between canaliculus and lacrimal sac.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles produce intorsion of eye ball:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Superior rectus and superior oblique

Both the Superiors are INtortors. i.e. Superior rectus and superior oblique muscles cause inward rotation (intortion) of the eyeball.

questions.text: Buccinator muscle is pierced by all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Buccal branch of facial nerve

• Buccal branch of facial nerve supplies buccinators but doesn’t pierce it.

• Buccinator muscle is ‘not’ pierced by buccal branch of facial nerve (or artery).

Buccal branch of mandibular nerve does pierce the buccinators muscle and supplies proprioceptive fibres to it.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a content of Carotid sheath?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sympathetic chain

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:  Sympathetic chain lies behind Carotid sheath and  is not its content.

choices.text: Enters the heart of level of 3rd costal cartilage
Receives azygos vein behind sterna angle

questions.text: NOT true about superior vena cava:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pierces pericardium at 3rd costal cartilage

• Superior vena cava pierces pericardium at the level of right 2nd costal cartilage and enters the right atrium at 3rd costal cartilage.

• Azygous vein terminate in the superior vena cava at the level of the 2nd costal cartilage (behind sterna angle).

questions.text: Attachment to the first rib are all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Scalenus posterior

• Scalenus posterior attaches to second rib.

• Other attachments on first ribs are: Subclavius, serratus anterior, costoclavicular ligament

questions.text: Left superior intercostals vein drains into:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Left brachiocephalic vein

• Left superior intercostals vein drains into the left brachiocephalic vein, whereas, right superior intercostals vein drains into azygous vein.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT intracapsular:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lateral epicondyle

• Lateral (and medial) epicondyles are outside the capsular ligament.

• The capsular ligament of the elbow joint is attached to the lower end along a line that reaches the upper limits of the radial and coronoid fossae  anteriorly and of the olecranon fossa posteriorly (these fossae are intracapsular).

choices.text: Radial nerve in the radial groove

questions.text: Finger drop with no wrist drop is caused by lesion of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Posterior interosseous nerve

• Injury to posterior interosseous nerve results in paralysis of extensor muscles in the posterior forearm.

• Finger drop (loss of finger extension at metacarpophalangeal joint) occurs, along with weakening of wrist extension.

• Wrist extension is still possible (no wrist drop) because of the functional ECRL (Extensor Carpi Radialis Longus) muscle, a powerful wrist extensor, already supplied by a branch of radial nerve proximal to the site of injury.

questions.text: A young girl complains of dryness of the nose and the palate. This would indicate a lesion of which of the following ganglia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Postganglionic parasympathetic fibers originating in the pterygopalatine ganglion innervate glands in the palate and nasal mucosa. The postganglionic parasympathetic fibers from the otic ganglion supply the parotid gland, those from the submandibular ganglion supply the submandibular and sublingual glands, and those from the ciliary ganglion supply the ciliary muscle and sphincter pupillae. The no dose (inferior) ganglion of the vagus nerve is a sensory ganglion.

choices.text: Sensory loss of the cornea and conjunctiva
Absence of the corneal blink reflex
Absence of sweating on the face

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman develops Bell palsy.She is worried because this can result in corneal inflammation ulceration. which of the following conditions will result in ulcer formation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Bell palsy (facial paralysis) can involve inflammation of the cornea, leading to corneal ulceration, which probably is attributable to an absence of the corneal blink reflex. 

• This is due to paralysis of the orbicularis oculi, which closes the eyelid. Sensory loss of the cornea and conjunctiva is due to injury of the ophthalmic nerve.

• Absence of sweating is due to damage of the sympathetic nerve. 

• Inability to constrict the pupil is due to paralysis of the sphincter pupillae or damage of parasympathetic nerve fibers to the sphincter.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman presents to your clinic with complaints of headache and dizziness. She has an infection of a cranial dural sinus. The sinus that lies in the margin of the tentorium cerebelli and runs from the posterior end of the cavernous sinus to the transverse sinus is infected. Which of the following sinuses is affected by inflammation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The superior petrosal sinus connects cavernous sinus to the transverse sinus along the attached margin of the tentorium cerebelli. This patient has meningitis which causes headache and dizziness.

choices.text: Vomer and perpendicular plate of ethmoid

questions.text:
During a gang fight, a 17-year-old boy is punched, and his nasal septum is broken.
Which of the following structures would be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The nasal septum is formed primarily by the vomer, the perpendicular plate of ethmoid bone, and the septal cartilage. The superior, middle, and inferior conchae form the lateral wall of the nasal cavity. The ethrnoid ( cribriform plate), nasal, frontal, and sphenoid (body) bones form the roof. The floor is formed by the palatine process of the maxilla and the horizontal plate of the palatine bone.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman comes to the hospital and complains of progressive loss of voice, numbness, loss of taste on the back part of her tongue, and difficulty in shrugging her shoulders.

Her MRI scan reveals a dural meningioma that compresses the nerves leaving the skull.

These nerves leave the skull through which of the following openings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A loss of voice is due to an injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve of the vagus nerve; numbness and loss of taste on the posterior part of the tongue are due to a lesion of the glossopharyngeal nerve; an inability to shrug the shoulder is due to damage of the accessory nerve. These three CNs exit the skull through the jugular foramen.

The foramen spinosum transmits the middle meningeal artery. The foramen rotundum transmits the maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve. The internal auditory meatus transmits the facial and vestibulocochlear nerves. The foramen lacerum transmits nothing, but its upper part is traversed by the internal carotid artery with sympathetic nerve plexus.

choices.text: Vagus nerve and middle cervical ganglion
Internal carotid artery and recurrent laryngeal nerve
Internal jugular vein and vagus nerve
Sympathetic trunk and common carotid artery

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman presents to her physician with a swelling on her neck. On examination, she is diagnosed with an infection within the carotid sheath. Which of the following structures would be damaged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The carotid sheath contains the internal jugular vein, vagus nerve, and common and internal carotid arteries. The recurrent laryngeal nerve lies in a groove between the trachea and esophagus. The sympathetic trunk, with superior and middle cervical ganglia, lies behind the carotid sheath. The external carotid artery is not contained within the carotid sheath. The ansa cervicalis lies superficial to or within the carotid sheath.

choices.text: Short ciliary, ophthalmic, and oculomotor nerves
Long ciliary, optic, and short ciliary nerves
Oculomotor, short ciliary, and optic nerves
Optic and long ciliary nerves and ciliary ganglion

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with multiple vision problems comes to the local eye clinic. The pupillary light reflex can be eliminated by cutting which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The efferent limbs of the reflex are involved in the pupillary light reflex (i.e., constriction of the pupil in response to illumination of the retina) and are composed of preganglionic parasympathetic fibers in the oculomotor nerve, parasympathetic fibers and ganglionic cells in the ciliary ganglion, and postganglionic parasympathetic fibers in the short ciliary nerves. The afferent limbs of this reflex are optic nerve fibers. The long ciliary nerves contain postganglionic sympathetic fibers. The ophthalmic nerve contains SA fibers.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy has difficulty in breathing because he is choking on food. A school nurse performs the Valsalva manoeuvre to expel air from his lungs and thus dislodge the food. When that fails, she performs a needle cricothyrotomy, which would open into which of the following regions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The infraglottic cavity extends from the rima glottidis to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. The rima glottidis is the space between the vocal folds and arytenoid cartilages. The vestibule extends from the laryngeal inlet to the vestibular folds.

The ventricle extends between the vestibular fold and the vocal fold. The piriform recess is a pear-shaped fossa in the wall of the laryngopharynx lateral to the arytenoid cartilage.

questions.text: A 59-year-old stroke patient is unable to swallow because of a nerve injury. Which of the following nerves is unaffected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The spinal accessory nerve supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles, which are not involved in the act of swallowing. Swallowing involves movements of the tongue to push the food into the oropharynx, elevation of the soft palate to close the entrance of the nasopharynx, elevation of the hyoid bone and the larynx to close the opening into the larynx, and contraction of the pharyngeal constrictors to move the food through the pharynx. The hypoglossal nerve supplies all of the tongue muscles except the palatoglossus, which is innervated by the vagus nerve. The vagus nerve innervates the muscles of the palate, larynx, and pharynx. The mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve supplies the suprahyoid muscles (e.g., the anterior belly of the digastric and the mylohyoid muscles).

questions.text: A 2-year-boy presents with midfacial and mandibular hypoplasia, cleft palate, deformed external ear, and defect in hearing. Which of the following embryonic structures is most likely developed abnormally?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

The patient's abnormal appearance results from abnormal development of the first pharyngeal arch because the first pharyngeal arch develops into muscles of mastication, mylohyoid, digastric anterior belly, tensor veli palatini, tensor tympani, maxilla, mandible, malleus, incus, zygomatic bone, temporal bone, palatine bone, vomer, and sphenomandibular ligament.

questions.text: Posterior superior alveolar artery is a branch of –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Palatal branch of maxillary 

Posterior superior alveolar artery is a branch of Palatal branch of maxillary whereas Anterior superior alveolar artery & Posterior superior alveolar artery are branches of Infraorbital Artery

questions.text: Exposure of left subclavian artery by supraclavicular approach does not require cutting of –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Scalenus Medius lies posterior to subclavian artery. 

Platysma, SCM, Sternohyoid, Sternothyroid, all lie anterior to first part. 

Scalenus anterior lies anterior to second part, whereas subclavius lies anterior & inferior belly is superior to third part of subclavian artery

questions.text: In serous acinus cell location of golgi
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Supranuclear

questions.text: What does ligamentum flavum contain
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Elastin

Exp: The ligamentum flavum is composed of elastin and collagen fibres. The elastin fibres provide elasticity to the ligament, while the collagen fibres provide stiffness and stability. 

If the question is asked like Which collagen is present in ligamentum flavum, then answer will be Collagen I but predominant fibres overall  is Elastin.

questions.text: Inversion muscles are all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Peroneus longus

It is an Eversion Muscle.

questions.text: A patient with syphilis presents with inabiity to walk with eyes closed. On examination Stamping gait is observed. Which of the following tract is involved ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dorsal Column. 

Exp: Posterior column disease which involves selective damaging of the posterior column, known as Tabes Dorsalis ( neurosyphilis).

A patient who has a problem with proprioception can still maintain balance by using vestibular function and vision. In the Romberg test, the standing patient is asked to close his or her eyes. An increased loss of balance is interpreted as a positive Romberg's test.

questions.text: All of the following take part in the articulation of Wrist joint except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ulna 

Exp: Although wrist joint is an articulation between forearm and hand, the medial bone of forearm — the ulna is excluded from this articulation by an articular disc.
